content: The "Renewable Energy from Agricultural Products (REAP) Act" allows for a credit for electricity produced from biomass. Extension and Modification of Placed-In-Service Rules for closed-loop biomass facilities under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 was modified on January 1, 2007, to include new rules for biomass facilities. These rules specify that a qualified facility using biomass must be in service before January 1, 2007. Additionally, special rules apply to certain qualified facilities, with the 10-year period starting from the enactment date of the rules. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 was amended to include rules for biomass facilities. These rules state that facilities in service before January 1, 1997, are exempt from certain provisions. Additionally, lessees of such facilities are treated as owners for tax purposes. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 was amended to include rules for biomass facilities, with exemptions for facilities in service before January 1, 1997. Biomass is defined as solid, nonhazardous, cellulosic waste material derived from forest-related resources and solid wood waste materials. The amendments made by this section apply to electricity sold after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR ELECTRICITY PRODUCED FROM AGRICULTURAL AND ANIMAL WASTE. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes adding agricultural and animal waste as a qualifying factor for tax credits. This waste includes heat, steam, and fuels produced from the conversion of agricultural and animal wastes, along with associated materials from processing, feeding, selling, transporting, and disposing of agricultural and animal products. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows agricultural and animal waste facilities to qualify for tax credits if they produce electricity. The amendment applies to facilities placed in service between December 31, 1992, and January 1, 2005, and is effective for electricity sold after the enactment of the Act.
